description.plain:
Mark Linkous (September 9, 1962 – March 6, 2010) was a singer-songwriter and musician who operated under the Sparklehorse moniker.

A member of the 1980s indie band the Dancing Hoods, Linkous moved with the group from his native Virginia to New York City and later Los Angeles in hopes of achieving mainstream success. By 1988, the band had failed to land a major record label deal, and they disbanded with Linkous returning to Virginia, where he began writing songs under various monikers.

By 1995, he created the project Sparklehorse, of which he would remain the only permanent member.

He committed suicide in Knoxville, Tennessee on March 6, 2010.

songs.title: 850 Double Pumper Holley

description.plain:
The voice for most of this track is that of Bob Rupe, co-founder and bassist of the Silos and bassist for Cracker, the band that pitched in considerably in the recording of Vivadixie.

The inquisitor who chimes in about the bass guitar is Mark Linkous.

songs.embed_content: Read “Bloody Hands” by Sparklehorse on Genius
songs.lyrics:
I can hear the owl
Stunted hands
Hissing quite slow
Across the frigid snows
And pictures of time
In an old woman's eye
Her hair is made of wood
And the moon beneath her feet

Barely awake on your snowy wings
This having stained your angel's hands
With my bloody hands

Your chest chills still haunt
The cells of my blood
And mingling stem frames
Are bold celluloid
To perch in the trees
And ram chimney tops
To burn away quite gradual
As wet morning fog

Barely awake on your snowy wings
This having stained your angel's hands
With my bloody hands
Barely awake on your snowy wings
This having stained your angel's hands
With my bloody hands

Barely awake on your snowy wings
This having stained your angel's hands
With my bloody handsEmbedShare URLCopyEmbedCopy

songs.full_title: Chaos of the Galaxy/Happy Man by Sparklehorse
songs.title: Chaos of the Galaxy/Happy Man

description.plain:
The eighth track from Good Morning Spider, “Chaos of the Galaxy/Happy Man” might have been the closest Linkous/Sparklehorse ever came to a radio hit, had not Linkous chopped this rocker into bits by interspersing radio static in the middle. In an interview, Linkous admitted the “sabotage” was deliberate on his part:

Yeah, the majority of it, for instance, the song “Happy Man”, I was really bored with it, and I made it sound like it was coming through an AM radio on the album, but so many people at the record company thought it should be a single, so I compromised, but compromised in a way that was still able to retain a lot of the integrity of the song.

The courage and the audacity it takes to deny your label a potential hit might make this the most punk thing a non-punk musician has ever done.

Nevertheless, at the urging of Eric Drew Feldman (one-time keyboardist for Captain Beefheart and bassist for PJ Harvey), Linkous reworked and remixed the song into a more radio-friendly edit.

songs.lyrics:
Oh come all you fellas so young and so fine
Seek not your fortune in a dark dreary mine

It'll form as a habit and seep in your soul
'Til the stream of your blood runs as black as the coal

Where it's dark as a dungeon, damp as the dew
Danger is double, pleasures are few
Where rain never falls, the sun never shines
It's dark as a dungeon, way down in the mine

Like a fiend with his dope, a drunkard with his wine
A man will have lust for the lure of the mine

And I pray when I’m dead my ages shall roll
That my body will blacken and turn into coal

And I look from the door, of my heavenly home
And pity the miner digging my bones

Where it's dark as a dungeon, damp as the dew
Danger is double, pleasures are few
Where the rain never falls, and the sun never shines
It's dark as a dungeon, way down in the mineEmbedShare URLCopyEmbedCopy

songs.title: Good Morning Spider

description.plain:
The fourth (and instrumental) track off Good Morning Spider shares the name of the album.

According to an interview with Richard Martin of CMJ, Linkous got the name from an old organ (a harmonium) that made mechanical sounds “like a spider building a web.” Later in France, he says in the same interview, someone told him of an old superstition that seeing a spider at night is a good omen and seeing one in the morning means “it’s gonna be a sad day.”  A pdf link to the entire interview can be found here.

This would be the first of three albums in Sparklehorse’s oeuvre in which Linkous would include a track sharing the name of the album, the other two being “It’s a Wonderful Life” and “Dreamt for Light Years in the Belly of a Mountain.” If we count “Dark Night of the Soul” from Linkous' collaboration with Danger Mouse and David Lynch, that means four successive albums with eponymous tracks.

Sadly, Linkous perversely denied us all the exquisite pleasure of a song called “Vivadixiesubmarinetransmissionplot.”

Every hair on your head is counted

Of people whose wings are just a blur

Looking for a good place to rest
Your head upon my chest
And I can feel the pillow of your breast

You are worth hundreds of sparrowsEmbedShare URLCopyEmbedCopy

songs.full_title: It's a Wonderful Life by Sparklehorse
songs.title: It’s a Wonderful Life

description.plain:
The lead track off the album of the same name, “It’s a Wonderful Life” was, acording to an interview with Linkous, a “fuck you” to critics who focused only on the darkness and depression in his lyrics.

That said, the name likely comes from the Jimmy Stewart Christmas film of the same name. In a different interview, with Richard Martin of CMJ, Linkous said  he had a cat on his farm he named after Jimmy Stewart. (He also had another cat he named after actor Robert Mitchum.) A pdf link to this entire interview can be found here.

primary_artist.name: Danny Elfman & Cast of the Nightmare Before Christmas

songs.lyrics:
Something's wrong with Jack
Something's wrong with Jack
Don't know if we're ever
Going to get him back

He's all alone up there
Locked away inside
Never says a word
Hope he hasn't died

Something's wrong with Jack
Something's wrong with Jack

Christmas time is buzzing in my skull
Will it let me be? I cannot tell
There's so many things I cannot grasp
When I think I've got it and then at last
Through my bony fingers it does slip
Like a snowflake in a fiery grip

Something's here, I'm not quite getting
Though I try, I keep forgetting
Like a memory long since past
Here in an instant, but gone in a flash

What does it mean?
What does it mean?
In these little bric-a-brac
A secret's ready to be cracked
These dolls and toys confuse me so
Confound it all, I love it though

Simple objects, nothing more
But something's hidden through a door
Though I do not have the key
Something's here I cannot see

What does it mean?
What does it mean?

I've read the Christmas books many times

The answer's right in front of me

Like music drifting in the air
Invisible but everywhere
Just because I cannot see it
And so I think this Christmas thing
It's not as tricky as it seems

And why should they have all the fun?
It should belong to anyone
Not anyone, in fact, but me
For I could make a Christmas tree

There's no reason I can find
I couldn't have a Christmas time
I bet I could improve it, too
And that's exactly what I'll doEmbedShare URLCopyEmbedCopy

songs.title: More Yellow Birds

description.plain: Much of this song alludes to a fatal mining accident, probably due to Carbon Monoxide poisoning. Mark Linkous (aka Sparklehorse) came from a family of coal miners.

songs.embed_content: Read “More Yellow Birds” by Sparklehorse on Genius

album.full_title: It’s a Wonderful Life by Sparklehorse
album.name: It’s a Wonderful Life

body.plain: Much of this song alludes to a fatal mining accident, probably due to Carbon Monoxide poisoning. Mark Linkous (aka Sparklehorse) came from a family of coal miners.

songs.lyrics:
Is your jewelry still lost in the sand?
Out on the coast, or rushed into the brine
You left your rings on the shoreline
So you wouldn't lose them, swimming in the shallows

A plastic shovel soft sweaty children far from home
On vacation not unlike your very own

And the Captain Howdy lit, upon my shoulder
And he left me with sulfur, and rooms full of headaches
I fell in with snakes, and the poison ranks of strangers
Please send me more yellow birds for the dim interior
Will my pony recognize my voice in hell?
Will he still be blind or do they go by smell?
Will you promise me not to rest me out at sea?
But on a fiery river boat that's rickety
I'll never find my pony along the rolling swells
A muddy river or a lake would do me well
With hints of amber sundowns and muted thunderstorms
A sunken barge's horns with the cold rusty bellsEmbedShare URLCopyEmbedCopy

songs.title: Morning Hollow

description.plain:
Ninth track of Dreamt for Light Years in the Belly of a Mountain, fourth and final album by Sparklehorse.

The song was previously found as the hidden bonus track on his third album It’s a Wonderful Life.

“Morning Hollow” features, among others, Tom Waits on piano and Linkous' frequent collaborator Sophie Michalitsianos on vocals.

songs.full_title: Sad and Beautiful World by Sparklehorse
songs.title: Sad and Beautiful World

description.plain:
The fifteenth and penultimate track on Vivadixie takes its title and signal refrain from a line uttered by Roberto Benigni in Jim Jarmusch’s 1986 film Down By Law, a film also starring Linkous' musical hero, Tom Waits.

In a 1996 interview for Rip It Up magazine, Linkous admitted he “definitely” took the line from the film, but the highly literate songwriter was quick to point out that “Benigni is quoting a Walt Whitman poem, so I’m borrowing from Walt Whitman.”

songs.title: Saint Mary

description.plain:
Following the critical success of Vivadixiesubmarinetransmissionplot (1995), Linkous entered a loose patronage under Radiohead, who encouraged him to travel on their European tour. It was during a layover in London that Linkous critically overdosed on a mixture of prescription antidepressants and alcohol, flooring him unconscious, his legs pinned beneath him, for fifteen consecutive hours. Following a heart attack and resuscitation three minutes later (between which he remained clinically dead), Linkous was admitted to St. Mary’s hospital, London, for a three-month convalescence.

This song is dedicated to the St. Mary’s staff who treated Linkous during his stay.




These lyrics are set to a soft, finger-plucked guitar melody not unlike a music box: it functions doubly as a means of settling Linkous into the vulnerable state of a child, while also lulling the listener along into a placid, similarly indolent state. Those familiar with a hospital atmosphere, especially in the place of a patient, may understand the long clinical drawl of the day, half-awake, half-asleep.




https://youtu.be/mA2-J0GApTU?t=6m7s

songs.title: Sick of Goodbyes

description.plain:
The fifth track on Good Morning Spider, “Sick of Goodbyes” was co-written by Mark Linkous and David Lowery–the latter of Camper Van Beethoven and Cracker fame. Linkous was a roadie for Cracker temporarily and the band helped him record much of Vivadixiesubmarinetransmissionplot (1995). The track also appears on Cracker’s 1993 album Kerosene Hat.

This kind of collaboration and cross-pollination was part of Linkous' MO. For example, “Dog Door,” which featured Tom Waits, appeared on Sparklehorses’s It’s a Wonderful Life and on Waits' 2006 collection Orphans.

Adding further to the cross-pollination, the song title comes from the Robert Frank photograph of the same name.

songs.full_title: Someday I Will Treat You Good by Sparklehorse
songs.title: Someday I Will Treat You Good
songs.title_with_featured: Someday I Will Treat You Good

description.plain:
The fourteenth track on Sparklehorse’s debut album, “Someday I Will Treat You Good” is the closest Linkous ever got to a radio hit, as the song got some play on alternative rock/college radio following the release of Vivadixie in 1995.

In addition to being a minor alt radio “hit,” the song somewhat stands apart from others on the album because, according to a 1996 Spin article, it was “penned during his days with a forgettable NYC pop band called the Dancing Hoods.”

That said, Linkous/Sparklehorse never totally left behind his pop sensibilities or his ability to write radio-friendly songs, as evidenced by the rocking tune he intentionally buried under static in “Chaos Of The Galaxy/Happy Man.”

songs.title: Weird Sisters

description.plain:
Like the start of “Homecoming Queen” (the previous track on this album), this title is another reference to Shakespeare in the title, this time from Macbeth:

The weird sisters, hand in hand,
Posters of the sea and land,
Thus do go about, about:
Thrice to thine and thrice to mine
And thrice again, to make up nine.
Peace! the charm’s wound up.

songs.full_title: Wish You Were Here by Sparklehorse (Ft. Thom Yorke)
songs.title: Wish You Were Here
songs.title_with_featured: Wish You Were Here (Ft. Thom Yorke)

description.plain:
Sparklehorse’s version of Pink Floyd’s “Wish You Were Here” was first released in 1997 on Come Again, a compilation, part of EMI’s 100th anniversary Essential series, in which EMI roster artists cover tunes from EMI’s catalog. In 1998 the song was released on the Painbirds / Maria’s Little Elbows single.

It features backing vocals (“Sang & Played His Hotel Telephone Over The Telephone”, quoting album credits) by Radiohead’s Thom Yorke. In 1996, shortly after the release of the album Vivadixiesubmarinetransmissionplot, Sparklehorse did an European tour with Radiohead as supporting act of the English band. This cover was probably recorded during that period.

In 2005 the song appeared on the soundtrack for 2005 skater film Lords Of Dogtown.

songs.title: Wish You Were Here

songs.lyrics:
So, so you think you can tell Heaven from Hell
Blue skies from rain
Can you tell a green field from a cold steel rail?
A smile from a veil?
Do you think you can tell?

Did they get you trade your heroes for ghosts?
Hot ashes for trees? Hot air for a cool breeze?
Cold comfort for change? Did you exchange
A walk on part in a war for a lead role in a cage?

How I wish, how I wish you were here
We're just two lost souls swimming in a fish bowl
Year after year
Running over the same old ground. What have we found?
The same old tears
Wish you were hereEmbedShare URLCopyEmbedCopy
